greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Iterate the map x -> A230625(x) starting at n; sequence gives the first prime (or 1) that is reached, written in base 2, or -1 if no prime is ever reached.
comment: _David J. Seal_ found that the number 255987 is fixed by the map described in A230625 (or equally A287874), so a(255987) = -1. (In fact 255987 is the smallest composite number that is fixed.) - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 15 2017

Also observe that the numbers 1007 and 1269 are mapped to each other by that map, as are the numbers 1503 and 3751 (see the b-file submitted by _Chai Wah Wu_ for A230625). So they are smaller composite values with a(n) = -1, though not fixed. - _David J. Seal_, Jun 16 2017
a(217) = a(255) = a(446) = a(558) = a(717) = a(735) = a(775) = a(945) = a(958) = -1 since the trajectory either converges to (1007,1269) or to (1503,3751). - _Chai Wah Wu_, Jun 16 2017
link: Chai Wah Wu, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..3931
mathematica: Table[FromDigits@ IntegerDigits[#, 2] &@ If[n == 1, 1, NestWhile[FromDigits[#, 2] &@ Flatten@ Map[IntegerDigits[#, 2] &, FactorInteger[#] /. {p_, 1} :> {p}] &, n, ! PrimeQ@ # &, {2, 1}]], {n, 37}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jun 24 2017 *)
xref: Cf. A230625, A230626, A230627 (where the primes reached are written in base 10).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jun 15 2017
ext: Changed the "escape" value from 0 to -1 to be consistent with A195264. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Jul 27 2017
